questions.question_text:
A systems administrator installed Git on a new workstation and wants to ensure all Git projects on this machine are initialized with the same username and email address.
Which of the following should the administrator use to meet this goal? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Although passwd and usermod both have password expiry date setting options, it is the man page of chage that confirms that when chage's expiry option is used, "A user whose account is locked must contact the system administrator before being able to use the system again."

questions.question_text:
A user tries to log in to the Linux console and receives the following message:
Your account has expired; Please contact your system administrator.
Which of the following commands was MOST likely run to create this behavior?

Joe, a user, asks a systems administrator to schedule the daily execution of a custom script.
Which of the following commands will allow the systems administrator to set up Joe's cron job?

discussion.content: -e Edit the current crontab, using the editor specified in the environment variable VISUAL or EDITOR.

I totally agree with Robertlars "If the answer is C then where did it pull that IP address from found in the answer since that IP was not part of the question itself? "
So I'm inclined towards D.

I think D is the right answer in this case.
nslookup is the name of a program that lets an Internet server administrator or any computer user enter a host name (for example, "whatis.com") and find out the corresponding IP address or domain name system (DNS) record.

Selected Answer: C
I thought D until....."The best way to test your reverse DNS configuration is using the command dig -x ipaddr +trace"

https://help.dyn.com/standard-dns/configuring-a-reverse-dns-zone-with-standard-dns/

If the answer is C then where did it pull that IP address from found in the answer since that IP was not part of the question itself? I don't think the answer was C, and I think it is D, but I honestly am not certain.

questions.question_text:
An administrator completed the configuration of the in-addr.arpa zone files for an organization.
Which of the following commands should the administrator use to verify the configuration is working as expected?
Which of the following is the BEST reason for not storing database files in the /var directory?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Make a subdirectory in /var for databases for back-up and clean-up management: https://askubuntu.com/questions/123335/using-var-log-to-backup-some-folders-database-contents
By default system logs are stored in: /var/log/

comments.content: It is considered to be against "best practice" methodology, i.e., please see: https://maximorlov.com/why-storing-files-database-bad-practice/

choices.C: Files in /var do not have strict file permissions.
choices.A: The /var filesystem is not fast enough for database files.
choices.D: If log files fill up /var, it might corrupt the database.
choices.B: The number of files in /var is limited by the available inodes.
